And maybe Uzziah would have never went in there and tried to offer the incense. Maybe Uzziah never would have become a leper. But when he was strong, his heart was lifted up to his destruction. In a positive sense, I want you to think about the Apostle Paul. In 2 Corinthians chapter number 12, we're familiar with the text of Scripture, and oftentimes we reference the ninth verse, my grace is sufficient for thee. But I want you to see some of what happens here in 2 Corinthians chapter number 12. Paul is speaking about, in 2 Corinthians chapter number 12, the visions and all that he had. He says of this in verse number 5, of such in one will I glory, yet of myself I will not glory, but in mine infirmities. Verse 6, for though I would desire to glory, I shall not be a fool, for I will say the truth. But now I forbear, lest any man should think of me above that which he seeth me to be, or that he heareth of me. He says this, unless I should be exalted above measure, notice this phrase, through the abundance of the revelations. You know, for many of us this morning, when we think about the Apostle Paul, when we reference the Apostle Paul, there are times in which we'll use this phraseology, he's the greatest Christian that ever lived. I've heard it many times, I've probably said it, but you know what Paul says of himself? I'm the chief of sinners. This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom I am chief. That's what Paul says. Paul understood that it was all about Jesus. He understood that he was on a road of religion, and he was going to die and spend eternity in a Christless eternity, separated from God. Why? Because he couldn't save them. He had zeal. He was lost. And God revealed Himself to him. And every time Paul had an opportunity to stand before people, you know what he did? He magnified the Lord. Let me tell you what Jesus did. Let me tell you how He changed my life. Let me tell you how I got saved. Remember that truth of Philippians 1 and verse number 20, that Christ would be magnified in my life, whether by life or by death. Paul says, lest I should be exalted above measure through the abundance of the revelations. Listen, we don't have the same kind of revelations that Paul is speaking of here today. But can I tell you, at times, sometimes we can be lifted up because of what we know. Sometimes we can think we're better than somebody else because of what we know. Being saved really doesn't make me better, it just makes me blessed. I mean, I'm going to a better place. I am blessed. I didn't do anything to get saved. I heard the gospel and I believed it. But I had nothing to do with hearing the gospel. And for many of you this morning, there's nothing you could do to have orchestrated you hearing the gospel. It is the grace of God. So I was born in a Christian home. Well, think about your parents and how somewhere, parents, grandparents, great-grandparents, somewhere along the line, the gospel came into your family and it was nothing to do with you. It's all because of God's grace. And Paul says, because of this, lest I should be exalted above measure, through the abundance of the revelations, notice what he says, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I should be exalted above measure. Paul acknowledged that it was this thing that God would use. Of course, he says that he prayed that God would deliver him, that it would depart from him, and God says, my grace is sufficient for thee, for my strength is made perfect in weakness. And then Paul then says, most gladly, therefore, will I rather glory in my infirmities that the power of Christ may rest upon me. Why? So that Christ would be magnified. He said, listen, I could have been, because of what's happened, I could have been exalted above measure. But isn't God so gracious on keeping us humble? And see, this morning, Paul says not only did he want to remain humble, we see that in Acts chapter number 20, but he says here in verse number 6, lest that any man should think of me above that which he seeth me to be, or that he heareth of me. And then we come to a place where Christ is being made known, because it's all about Christ in my life and your life, individually and corporately. It's about magnifying Christ, and it helps us to stay humble. My feet stay on the ground, why? Because it's all about Jesus. It's all about Jesus. This morning, I hope that we'd have a resolve to magnify the Lord. I hope that when we see the resolve of the psalmist and of Mary and of John the Baptist and of Paul, that we'd say, I want to have that settled determination that in my life, let God be magnified. I'm poor and needy, but He's wonderful. He's more than wonderful. He's my God. And let me tell you what He's done for me. Let God be magnified. Father, we love You. We thank You for loving us. Help us as we magnify Your name individually and corporately to make You known.
